instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1990: What is A1990? A1990 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2018, 2019 with EMC3215, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01041, 820-01814..
definitions.820-01041: What is 820-01041? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA? This is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad. Each CD3215 in the system needs to be functioning in order for any of them to speak to the charger and negotiate receiving 20v from the charger rather than the default 5v that a USB-C charger puts out before communicating with the system. .
definitions.USBC_XB_CC1: What is USBC_XB_CC1? USBC_XB_CC1 is a line between the USB-C muxing chip such as the CD3217 or CD3215 and the USB-C charger. Communication must happen on this line in order for the USB-C charger to put out 20v..
definitions.USBC_XB_CC2: What is USBC_XB_CC2? USBC_XB_CC2 is a line between the USB-C muxing chip such as the CD3217 or CD3215 and the USB-C charger. Communication must happen on this line in order for the USB-C charger to put out 20v..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_AWAKE: What is PP1V8_AWAKE? The PP1V8_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is indicative of a power rail that delivers 1.8 volts when the machine is in an "awake" state. This is not a traditional power state defined in the older Intel PCH documentation; it seems to be specific to newer MacBook architectures. The "awake" designation likely refers to a state where the MacBook is on and ready for user interaction, but it is not necessarily at full operational capacity (which would be denoted by an S0 state).
definitions.PP1V2_AWAKE: What is PP1V2_AWAKE? The PP1V2_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides 1.2 volts and is associated with the machine's awake state and is used for powering the T2 chip..

threads.title: MacbookPro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A USBC Problem
threads.message:
Hi

I have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board. Previously it was having liquid damage one <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> and both ports were burnt out. After replacement of both port and one <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>, it started working and i was getting 20V and normal current without battery. But after some one of the new Port burnt out suddenly and damaged again one more <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>. then i realised that that port were faulty and found one more faulty in the same lot i ordered from supplier. Again i did replacement of <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>. before that replacement, behaviour of three port was similar except this. i was getting <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> on three port but not on that i replaced later. 

But after that i am not getting <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>. it shows 5.14V on all ports. But i am getting PP3V3G3H from all ports. 
one more thing that i wants to highlights, two of the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> has C00 number in last and other two has B03.  Does it make any difference?

what else do i need to check?

Thanks

threads.title: MacbookPro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A USBC Problem
threads.message:
Yeah, big difference; NOT compatible in fact.
Solder correct chips first.

threads.title: MacbookPro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A USBC Problem
threads.message:
Hi
Sorry for that long delay, i was waiting for the ICs. NOW I have soldered the all same CD3215C00 on board but still the same problem. i am getting 5V at USB-C Meter.
I have checked couple of power rails which are as follows.
1. <SIGNAL>PP_20V_USB_XB_VBUS</SIGNAL>---5V
2. PP3V#_UPC_XB_LDO--3.3V
3. <SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA</SIGNAL>--1.8V
4. <SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD</SIGNAL>--1.8V
5. <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XB_BMC</SIGNAL>---1.1
6. <SIGNAL>HV_GATE1</SIGNAL>-- 10.9V
7. <SIGNAL>HV_GATE2</SIGNAL>-- 5.V
8. <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>--5V
9. <SIGNAL>CHGR_VDDA</SIGNAL>--5V
10. <SIGNAL>CHGR_VDDP</SIGNAL>--5V
11. <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>--3.3V
12. <SIGNAL>USBC_XB_CC1</SIGNAL>--0V
13. <SIGNAL>USBC_XB_CC2</SIGNAL>--0V
14. <SIGNAL>CHGR_AUX_DET</SIGNAL>--1.2 V 

what else do i need to check? is it TBAROM need to be replaced?

threads.title: MacbookPro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A USBC Problem
threads.message: Do you get 1V1 LDO voltage on all <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips?

threads.title: MacbookPro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A USBC Problem
threads.message:
i didn't notice that need to check on all.
i am not getting on two <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>. these are UB300 and UB400.
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_TA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>---0V
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_TB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>---0V
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>---1.1V
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>---1.1V

other two <SIGNAL>LDO_1V8A</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>LDO_1V8D</SIGNAL> is ok on both these ICs.

threads.title: MacbookPro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A USBC Problem
threads.message:
1V1 LDO only appears on the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chip corresponding to powered port.
Did you check correctly?
Missing this LDO, usually denotes bad chip.

threads.title: MacbookPro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A USBC Problem
threads.message:
i have tried with second pair IC (New) and still no 1.1V LDO on both Ics with corresponding port.
It means the complete lot of the ICs are is faulty. I bought 12 Ics -Six each in C00 and B03.   tried 4 of them (CD3215C00). ..

threads.title: MacbookPro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A USBC Problem
threads.message:
I prefer to remove chips from scrap boards.
I had too many problems with "new" chips...

threads.title: MacbookPro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A USBC Problem
threads.message:
Hi
i have question regarding this problem.i am getting 5V on all ports and its taking 380mAmp through each port so the behaviour is same at all ports. is it normal that much current. Any way i am waiting for scrap board. then will try. can you please make me understand communication with TBROM? if possible just in short.

threads.title: MacbookPro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A USBC Problem
threads.message:
380mA without any cable connected to MLB?
Post exact <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> voltage.
Do you get all SLPS2R and AWAKE voltages?
Is the machine recognized in DFU mode?

threads.title: MacbookPro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A USBC Problem
threads.message:
Hi Vali
Thanks for your support and sharing your experience. Really i am learning a lot from you. 

I don't have another machine for DFU Mode at the moment, waiting for that. But as you asked to check some voltages are here What we can assume from these voltages
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 12.32V.
PP1V8SLPSLPS2R- 1.8V.
PP1V1SLPS2R -1.1V
PP1V8SLPS2R- 0.8V
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_AWAKE</SIGNAL>- 1.2V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_AWAKE</SIGNAL>- 1.8V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_AWAKE</SIGNAL>- 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP3V0_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL>- 3.0V

threads.title: MacbookPro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A USBC Problem
threads.message:
Get a machine with SAME macOS installed and try DFU mode.
Read other related threads, all the information is on the forum.
